Questa lingua barbara derivata dalla romana e chiamata allora e anch'oggi romanza, ed esistente vivissima in alcuni paesi, aveva sotto il lungo dominio de' Romani e le perpetue colonie militari, abolite, se non estinte, le diverse lingue nazionali dei popoli, – come la lingua inglese d'oggi ha fatto e farà sempre più dimenticare i dialetti parlati dagli antenati della Scozia, dell'Irlanda e degli abitanti di Galles: – e come avviene nell'inglese parlato oggi dagli Scozzesi e Irlandesi. Ma la lingua romana, adattandosi agli organi di popoli di differenti climi e d'abitudini e lingue diverse, o quantunque in sostanza la lingua romanza, divenne modificazione apparentemente diversa in ogni provincia d'Europa.

Di questi dialetti rimangono documenti scarsissimi, perchè la lingua letteraria continuava ad essere pur sempre la latina, barbaramente scritta e nella quale si pubblicavano le leggi, i decreti, gl'istrumenti legali, – e quel poco che i maestri poteano insegnare lo dettavano in latino, primamente perchè sinchè i Romani dominarono, vollero che nelle faccende pubbliche la loro lingua fosse anche intesa da tutti i loro sudditi; in seguito perchè all'invasione de' barbari il Clero rimase erede degli avanzi della giurisprudenza, della legislazione e della lingua latina, e nessuno sapea scrivere fuorchè il Clero, – e finalmente perchè i popoli settentrionali generalmente doveano servirsi di una lingua nella quale le leggi erano scritte, e che, se non intesa dal popolo, era pure interpretata da' legali e da' maestri delle scuole, da' preti, da' monaci e da' vescovi, che in quasi tutta l'Europa d'allora ottenevano una grande preponderanza.

Pur la questione sarebbe involta in congetture, se di questi ultimi anni un letterato italiano, che da pochi mesi non vive più, non avesse con somma industria e con eguale imparzialità raccolti ed esaminati quanti avanzi scritti rimanevano della lingua romanza anteriori al secolo di Dante, e, paragonandoli l'uno all'altro, riescì a convincere sè medesimo e i suoi lettori che quegli scritti, benchè di diversi paesi d'Italia, e talvolta anche di diversi popoli d'Europa, quantunque differissero nella terminazione delle parole, e in alcune varietà di sintassi, erano nondimeno composti degli stessi vocaboli, e con la stessa legge grammaticale; cosicchè tutti possono con pochissime alterazioni essere letteralmente tradotti nella lingua italiana d'oggi.

Gl'Italiani, e sopratutto i Fiorentini, conservarono più gran numero di voci latine, sì perchè continuavano ad abitare il paese dove la lingua latina era stata la lingua nazionale, e dove era la sede de' pontefici e la gerarchia della [Chiesa] e che continuavano a servirsi di latino; – e continuavano a pronunziare i vocaboli della lingua romanza men corrotti che dagli altri Italiani; sì perchè la Toscana fu meno che altro paese d'Italia sotto il diretto governo de' conquistatori settentrionali, e i loro organi avvezzi a pronunziare le parole intere, lunghe e rotonde del latino, erano stati preservati nella stessa abitudine, parte dalla mollezza del clima, e parte dal poco commercio co' popoli del Nord.

Molte parole nondimeno delle lingue teutoniche restarono alla lingua letteraria italiana; e v'è un criterio sicuro per distinguerle. Rare, se pur ve n'è alcune, riguardano la vita domestica e gli usi comuni della vita, che non siano latine; ma le parole appartenenti a cose di guerra o titoli militari sono teutoniche, e sottentrano a quelle de' Romani. Così brando, elmo, panciera, – invece di ensis o gladium, o galea; – marciare, – marescalco, invece di proficisci o procedere, e Dux; e, per lasciare altri esempi, invece del latino bellum dissero guerra da war, donde venne il nome de' Germani di Warman. – Lo stesso avvenne, benchè più tardi, per altri oggetti in Inghilterra e fu al tempo delle conquiste normanne; perchè le voci esprimenti bue, vitello, porco, agnello, montone, – ed altre necessità della vita somministrate dalla agricoltura, restarono sassoni nella campagna; ma i soldati, andandoli a comprare al mercato o fors'anche il conquistatore avendo disposta una tariffa, prevalsero con il tempo e restarono alla cucina i nomi franco-romanzi di veal, beef, mutton.
Come la lingua italiana abbia troncato e modificato le terminazioni della latina, e sia ricorsa agli articoli, non è difficile a intendersi.

Così, sino al secolo XII tutte le provincie italiane parlavano la lingua romanza più o meno modificata nella pronunzia, secondo il genere d'organi loro naturali, e più o meno arricchita di. parole forestiere, secondo che era stata generata da diverse nazioni forestiere, e il contatto e commercio che essa aveva tenuto con esse. Così i Napolitani e Siciliani non hanno quasi parole di origine teutonica, e ne hanno di arabiche e di normanne; – i Genovesi, e più ancora i Veneziani, che navigavano in Grecia e sulle coste dell'Affrica, hanno molte voci di origine greca e alcune di origine arabica che sono poi passate nella lingua toscana e in tutte le lingue d'Europa; come fra l'altre: Ammiraglio, – in inglese Admiral; – Arzanà, come Dante lo scrive, e Darzena come lo pronunziano i Genovesi, ed Arsenal, come oggi è proferito da' Veneziani; e in italiano scrivesi Arsenale, e Arsenal in inglese, onde il dottore Johnson a torto lo chiamò vocabolo d'origine italiana, quando è pretto affricano; se non che pare che il dottor Johnson non abbia giudicato che etimologie e derivazioni delle parole fossero degne del suo studio. Ma, se di tanto uomo è permesso di dire meno che lodi, egli avrebbe fatto da savio disprezzandole e tralasciandole affatto; ma, avendole ammesse nel suo dizionario degnate di esame, pare che egli disprezzasse anche i suoi lettori.

Nel duodecimo secolo, quando si cominciò più o meno a scrivere la lingua romanza, gli Italiani cominciarono a chiamarla volgare per distinguerla dalla latina, e il nome di romanza restò alla provenzale; la quale fu chiamata linguotta.

Per un capriccio singolare delle lingue, la latina ch'era parlata da un popolo di conquistatori, dal popolo più assoluto o, per valermi della nozione inglese, dal più positivo popolo della terra, mancava dell'affermazione positiva. Non vi è nel latino un termine apposito esclusivamente per affermare; però affermando dicevano utique, – oppure hoc, hoc, – e sic, sic ed altre espressioni. Dall'utique mozzato venne l'oui nella Francese in settentrione, dall'hoc venne l'hoc de [lla] Francia meridionale; e però la lingua provenzale fu chiamata la lingua del hoc, quindi il nome della provincia di Linguadoca; – e dal sic più usitato in Italia venne il nostro sì. – E questa osservazione illustra il verso di Dante che, alludendo alla Toscana, la definisce del bel paese là dove il sì suona, e spesso nelle sue prose ei chiama il provenzale la lingua dell' hoc.

Ma la Provenza aveva avuto una corte e principi e gli uomini più distinti d'Europa, e alcuni negli ultimi tempi delle Crociate, molto innanzi che l'Italia si fosse affatto riscossa dal giogo teutonico; però quella lingua fu scritta innanzi della italiana, e diventò letteraria; cosicchè Brunetto Latini maestro di Dante, volendo scrivere più per la gente.educata che pe' letterati di professione, e non essendovi a' tempi suoi nè molti scrittori, nè molti lettori di lingua italiana, s'appigliò a scrivere il suo trattato di Rettorica e Filosofia in lingua romanza provenzale, perch'era intesa da tutti.

Ma la poesia che precede la prosa in tutti i paesi, e più in climi ed età dove regnano le immaginazioni e le passioni, era stata coltivata in lingua romanza chiamata siciliana, cinquanta anni innanzi di Dante, secondo il suo proprio computo; e i poeti siciliani incominciarono a ridurre la lingua italiana al grado di letteraria. Quindi le due asserzioni di Dante e di Petrarca, asserzioni che divisero e divideranno per lungo tempo i grammatici antiquari, si accordano mirabilmente. Perchè molte lingue romanze italiane, senz'essere formate dalla romanza provenzale, e la siciliana, esistevano contemporaneamente; e quando di queste differenti gli scrittori cominciarono a farne una sola generale ed intelligibile a tutta l'Italia, spogliandola de' latinismi, de' francesismi e de' plebeismi, vi tennero tutte le parole utili e le frasi eleganti che appartenevano tanto alle lingue romanze di Francia, quanto a quelle d'Italia e di Sicilia.

Nè Dante e Petrarca allegarono un'opinione differente su questo proposito con l'intenzione di decidere della origine della lingua; – questi due poeti non alludevano che ai Trovatori, come allora si chiamavano gli scrittori di rime, che oggi si onorano del titolo di poeti. Senza intendere di decidere un punto d'antichità, Dante affermava agli Italiani che dovevano coltivare la loro lingua materna, scriverla invece della latina, e non arricchire di opere la Francia, componendo in galetto romanzoprovenzale, – ma scegliere piuttosto il dialetto romanzo-siciliano, che era men aspro, più pieno. di vocali e più. vicino e conforme agli organi ed alla pronunzia degli Italiani, e [in] conseguenza più intelligibile; ma che per altro non bisognava addottare nessun dialetto romanzo particolare, ma combinare il meglio di tutti e formare una lingua universale a tutta l'Italia; e Dante diede i precetti e l'esempio; ed oltre le rime e il poema, scrissein prosa italiana de' trattati ammirabili per la lingua, e di tale stile stampandoli, che con pochissime alterazioni di ortografia parrebbero scritti oggi. Petrarca al contrario non ha mai considerato la lingua italiana come capace di trattare soggetti in prosa: a scrisse seriamente e gravemente per ambizione di fama opere in latino, nè mai scrisse in italiano se non in versi per descrivere la sua passione; e anch'egli, come Dante, si formò una lingua tutta sua propria, scegliendo e combinando i più eleganti ed espressivi ed armoniosi vocaboli ed idiomi da molti vari dialetti romanzi sì italiani che francesi. – Ma tanto Dante che Petrarca, avendo succhiato il loro dialetto materno col latte di madri e nudrici fiorentine, dovevano necessariamente [avere] il dialetto toscano per fondo della loro lingua italiana scritta; ma non ritennero, per così dire, che l'ossatura, perchè col potere del loro genio ciascuno de' due si creò una lingua nuova. Quella di Dante è più originale e più italiana, sì perchè fu il primo, e sì perchè aveva ricavati materiali del suo stile da vari dialetti d'Italia; e quella del Petrarca è più elegante e più raffinata di frasi, sì perchè egli, essendo venuto dopo, perfezionò molti modi di lingua introdotti da altri, e essendo stato educato da giovinetto in Provenza, dove abitò lungamente, ed amò, e scrisse le sue poesie amorose, si servì più che Dante di idiomi del romanzo-provenzale, e diede ai Provenzali il merito, forse vero forse non vero, d'avere introdotto non la lingua, ma i metri delle poesie italiane. Ed in questo particolare vedremo che si ingannò; perchè la forma del sonetto fu trovata in Sicilia, e la forma della canzone lunga è tutta d'invenzione toscana. Questi due grandi uomini, e il Villani loro contemporaneo, ed altri storici, e poscia il Boccaccio contribuirono grandemente alla diffusione e popolarità del dialetto toscano in Italia e al fondamento della lingua letteraria italiana. Ma, anche senza questi grandi scrittori, il dialetto toscano aveva acquistato da sè qualità che rendevano migliore di tutti gli altri dialetti italiani. Aveva, come s'è detto, più numero di parole latine ed indigene, per così dire, all'Italia e più confacentisi a una lingua letteraria;aveva ne' vocaboli conservato più rotondità di pronunzia. Avevano i Toscani, e l'hanno tuttavia i Fiorentini, i Pistoiesi e Sanesi, fra gli altri, una corretta. modulazione naturale di suoni nell'esprimere le parole. La Repubblica di Firenze era democratica, e il genere umano in tutti i paesi è destinato a essere strascinato per le sue lunghissime orecchie: ne' paesi liberi e dove il popolo fa leggi, i suoi conduttori devono essere eloquenti. – E, col parlare continuo in pubblico, gli uomini creati dalla natura per essere eloquenti diventano oratori, ed arricchiscono e perfezionano la loro lingua. Finalmente, per un singolare concorso di circostanze, ogni padre di famiglia in Firenze teneva un registro domestico di quanto accadeva nella sua casa e siccome dal più ricco al più povero tutti si credevano membri non solo della loro famiglia, ma anche della Repubblica, tutti ne' loro diari mescevano le faccende pubbliche così che, esercitandosi a parlare in pubblico e scrivere di cose importanti, la lingua acquistava perfezione, esattezza e colore. Molti di questi manoscritti furono pubblicati, e sono davvero tesori di lingua, di composizione e di storia. Leggendoli, il grammatico si meraviglia della correzione della sintassi nell'elocuzione, – il critico non sa come spiegare quella spontanea, secreta e però tanto più potente arte ed ordine di stile e lo storico vi trova particolarità e date e riflessioni politiche che sarebbero a sfuggite anche al genio d'Erodoto e Tacito. A questo esercizio di facoltà naturali aggiungevasi il profitto che ritraevano dal tradurre gli scrittori latini, e quasi sempre in prosa, – spesso non intendendoli perfettamente, ma le traduzioni de' classici seri, comunque siano fatte quanto alla fedeltà, servono mirabilmente a portare varietà, novità ed abbondanza e nobiÏtà ad una lingua; sopratutto se la lingua è vivente e docilissima.agli innesti. – Tale è il carattere generale degli scrittori fiorentini, durante il secolo illustre per Dante, Petrarca e Boccaccio; nel qual tempo, per un fenomeno di cui io non ho mai udito, nè ho mai saputo trovare la spiegazione in nessuno di quegli scrittori fiorent[ini,] molti de' quali artigiani, e le opere de' quali si trovano tuttavia manoscritte a centinaia, non si trova una sola inesattezza grammaticale; mentre nelle rarissime lettere che Petrarca scriveva in fretta in italiazio, alle volte non v'è grammatica.

Ma la lingua italiana non rimase in questo stato di prosperità più di un secolo; perchè poco più di trent'anni dopo la morte del Boccaccio non vi fu, per così dire, più nè scrittore, nè lingua. Tutti gli uomini dotti si vergognavano di scrivere in altra lingua fuorchè in latino, – e fra l'anno 1400 e l'anno 1480, in cui comincia l'epoca celebre di Lorenzo. de' Medici, appena troviamo tre o quattro scrittori che meriti[no] d'essere studiati per la correzione. Fra l'altre ragioni che si paleseranno da sè, allorchè il corso di queste letture ci condurrà a quell'epoca, ve n'è una non osservata, ch'io mi sappia, da quanti trattano la storia della letteratura italiana; ed è, che i padri e i maestri, per favorire lo studio del greco e del latino, proibivano non solo [lo] scrivere in italiano, ma lo studiare gli autori più celebri della loro patria. II Varchi, che era giovinetto verso la fine dell'epoca di Lorenzo de' Medici, scrive ingenuamente di sè e del suo maestro; ed io citerò le sue parole: a «Quando il magnifico Giuliano fratello di papa Leone era vivo, che sono più di quaranta anni passati, ..... la lingua fiorentina, come che altrove non si stimasse molto, era in Firenze per la maggior parte in dispregio: e mi ricordo io, quando era giovanetto che il primo e più severo comandamento che facevano generalmente i padri a' figliuoli, e i maestri a' discepoli, era che eglino nè per bene, nè per male non leggesseno cose volgare (per dirlo barbaramente, come loro); e maestro Guasparri Mariscotti da Marradi, che fu nella gramatica mio precettore, uomo di duri e rozzi, ma di santissimi e buoni costumi, avendo una volta inteso, in non so che modo, che Schiatta di Bernardo Bagnesi ed io leggevamo il Petrarca di nascoso, ce ne diede una buona grida, e poco mancò che non ci cacciasse di scuola».

div2.n: Origin and vicissitudes of the italian language
div2.head: ORIGIN AND VICISSITUDES OF THE ITALIAN LANGUAGE
(Preliminary to the Criticism of particular Works)
div2.p: Under a decree of the Grand Duke of Tuscany, the Della Crusca Academy of Florence has lately proposed to give a premium of 500 scudi (about L. 200 Sterling), to that writer who shall demonstrate, In what manner, and at what period it has happened, that the Roman language, in its various alterations, has given birth to the Italian, Provençal, and French dialects? What have been the changes that have, in an especial manner, contributed to give to the Italian tongue a peculiar and distinctive character? What were the occasions on account of which, and at what era, Italian first began to be written? At what period did the language of Italian authors, assume a remarkable distinction from that of the people? What degree of influence had the dialect of the people upon the language of authors, and the language of authors upon the dialect of the people? In what part of Italy has the dialect of the people most approximated itself to the language of their authors? Have the Sicilian poets at all affected the language used by Italian writers? Whether, among the several Italian dialects there was any which had obtained a preeminence above the rest before the age of Dante, of Petrarca, of Boccaccio; and whether the Tuscan itself has been assisted by their labours i Whence has it happened. that the Italian tongue, matured to a greater degree of perfection than any other of the languages of Europe derived from the Latin, and herself, the daughter most resembling that mother, should not have been on all occasions employed, in preference to other languages, in the reciprocal relations of European States?

Of the numerous dissertations presented at the close of the last year, not one was considered by the Florentine academicians to have merited the premium which had been proposed; and to one only of the competitors they barely conceded the barren praise of an honourable mention; not because he had satisfied the questions propounded, but because, perhaps, he had written upon them less absurdly than his opponents. At present theAcademy, and the Sovereign who is its protector, convinced apparently of the difficulty of the subject proposed have enlarged the term for a fresh competition, to the last day o the year 1826. But either we greatly deceive ourselves, or their questions will never be solved. The subject is one of extreme difficulty, as well on account of the darkness of those ages out of the grave of which the facts to be collected must be disinterred, as of the difficulty of perspicuously explaining, and of applying to the facts themselves, those abstract principles of ideology that are indispensable to the tracing the origin and progress of languages. Obstacles, however, as these are, they will yield to learning, perseverance, and genius. But no human faculty, having once become enchained, can ever be freed from its bondage without first bursting through its fetters. That obstacle, which to us appears equivalent to a moral impossibility, consists in fact in the silence which the state of Italy imposes upon the agitation of all political matters. The Italian language was produced, and grew, and attained its perfection with the republics of the middle ages; and it became weakened, miswritten, and corrupted, under those absolute and foreign governments which afterwards occupied Italy. Now, according to the conditions stipulated in the programme of the Academy, the author of a paper, although he should be declared worthy of the premium, cannot demand it, unless his manuscript have previously been printed; and in the print he cannot adopt any alterations of any kind, without submitting them anew to the judgment of the Academy. Or, in other words, a dissertation of this kind may be a chef-d'œuvre; the Florentine Academy, Italy, all Europe may approve it; the cause of literature may derive from it glory and advantage; but because, without the examination of the political censorship, and the "Imprimatur" of ecclesiastical inquisitors, no book can now be printed in Italy, and the Academy will never countenance things that are discountenanced by the inquisition and the prince, – no author really deserving of this prize will ever obtain it; and if any should obtain it, he will not have deserved it. This our prediction as to the future, which is independent of the consideration of what has happened in the past, will be strengthened by certain general indications in the course of our argument; and if the plan and the limits of a periodical work preclude us from answering severally to the questions propounded by the Della Crusca Academicians, we shall at least expound so much of the matter as may sufficiently prove, that the academies, the universities, and the governments of Italy, will only arrive at the history of its language, when they shall permit their authors to examine in what manner, and to what extent, the improvement and the decline of languages depend upon the liberty or the thraldom of nations.

The Italian language has always been a purely literary one. It has never been generally spoken as written; and if some of the early Tuscans did write it as they spoke it, they employed, not so much the general idiom, as a dialect which, being the most elegant among those of Italy, naturally approximated itself to the literary language of the nation. Thus it happened, that that language was not subjected to those vicissitudes and those remarkable alterations which the lapse of years produces in the pronunciation, the orthography, and the words of spoken languages; and the stock of phrases and of words that remained deposited in the productions of the older writers, has successively passed into such increased credit and usage, that they have been employed (sometimes with. success, and at others without it) by the numerous authors who have written, from Dante down to our times.

To Dante, – to whom nobody will deny the title of the creator of the poetical language of Italy, – belongs moreover the praise of having left us models of pure, elegant, and energetic prose; and he availed himself of so few of those phrases that have fallen into desuetude, that his works have always appeared written for the present age. But he did still more; for while the language was in its infancy, as it were, he established it upon theories that have not been attained to in other languages until after the lapse of many generations. The doctrine that was suggested to him by his own eminently philosophic mind, was so founded in truth, that one would be almost tempted to believe he must have been aided by the spirit of prophecy. He found that the dialects were numerous, various, and discordant, in the same ratio with the number of cities, the diversity of manners, and the political disunion of the Italian provinces; and he established it as an incontestable maxim, that the language should be derived and carried to its perfection, not by reference to any one particular dialect, but by combinations of the most elegant, harmonious, and forcible words and phrases, which authors could select from all the various dialects of Italy, and by incorporating them into one literary language common to the whole nation.

All these dialects were derived from the Latin, which was at that time more written than it was spoken. Every city and free town, during the prosperity of the Roman empire, still retained its own peculiar dialect, the idioms. of which were purified and ennobled by the genius and the tastè of orators and authors. The patavinity of Livy, however incredible a mystery it may appear to the professors of our universities, was not at all unintelligible to the learned men of Rome. Cicero mentions some most eloquent orators; and he says of them, that they would have left to posterity models of composition, if, instead of speaking Roman, they had spoken Latin". And Julius Cæsar, in order to establish the literary language of his country upon more certain principles, composed a treatise, of which unfortunately only a few fragments remain to us. But the continual arrival of foreigners from the remote provinces of the empire, in all the cities of Italy, imported so many new words and phrases, that the provincial and municipal dialects, so far from approximating more nearly to the Latin tongue, became constantly more different from one another; and finally, this diversity was still more increased by the novelty of the customs, the laws, and the languages, that were brought into Italy by the various nations who from the north invaded the south, and there founded different governments and dynasties. Then it was that Italy, who had subdued all Europe by her conquests, lost, not only the practice of the military art, but even at length the very names of arms; and the words of Teutonic origin that have been retained in the Italian language, are precisely those which appertain to arms. Thus, the word "bellum" was forgotten, and supplied by the word "wár", which is altered into "guerra"; the words, "gladius", and "ensis", have been replaced by "brando" and "spada", (in the Teutonic "brand", "spade"). And so of the rest. The conqueror, while he cited his own military dictionary, took from the vanquished the terms of luxury and of arts that were unknown to him. In the same manner the Normans imposed upon the English not only the formulary and the language of their law, but the vocabulary, moreover, of the kitchen; and while in that country the ancient names still subsist of "ox, calf, pig", the French soldiers, and probably also the edicts of the government for regulating the prices of commodities, made use of words that belonged to the Romance language, such as "boeuf, veaul, porc", which English pronunciation has rendered by "beef, veal, pork", and which are all derived from the "bos", "vitulus", and "porcus", of the Latins.

Nevertheless the Latin, although, upon the decline of the Roman empire, it became exceedingly corrupt and barbarized by the intermixture of so many foreign words, remained diffused over all the countries of Europe into which the Romans in preceding ages had pushed their conquests, and wherein they had established governments and colonies. Hence arose two languages, general and common to the whole of Europe; the barbarous Latin prevailing in books and in the acts of the clergy, in the schools and in the tribunals, – and the Romance language, which was spoken in various dialects by the common people. Those questions which have been so long agitated, – as to whether the Provençal have ' enriched their language and their poetry with the spoils of the Sicilian dialect, and whether the Italian is indebted for its formation to the Catalonian dialect and to the French, – would have subsided very long ago, had they not served to gratify the miserable vanity of the pedants of learning, as well as illiberal national animosities. All the national and provincial dialects derived from the corrupt Latin, although they were remarkably various, appertained to that common language anciently designated "the Roman of the capital of the western empire", and afterwards "the Romance"; precisely as has happened with the Greek which is spoken in our days, and which has been denominated "the Romaic", ever since the period in which the Roman emperors transferred themselves into the east. The more immediate and least doubtful origin, therefore, of the literary Italian seems to be ascertained, by ascribing it to the Romance language, which was then modified from the dialect peculiar to the inhabitants of Italy, and especially to the Tuscans. Sordello, in Lombardy, had written in the Romance language, two centuries before the birth of Dante; nor had the Tuscans, for a century and a half before Dante's time, written in a dialect very different from that of the Sicilians; and from fragments which are still subsisting, it appears that the Sicilians, the Provençals, the Italians, the Lombards, and the Tuscans, must have reciprocally understood one another. The difference of dialects between nation and nation, and province and province, consisted chiefly in the difference of their orthography, arising in part from the infancy in which the art of writing was in these times, and in part also from that difference of pronunciation, which, after all, forms the diversity of languages, and which depends upon the peculiar conformation of organs that nature has assigned in infinite variety to the different races of the earth.

From several of the laws and treaties of the princes of the middle ages, as also from private contracts that are still preserved in our archives, and from some of the letters of the few who in those days could write, it evidently appears, that while every description of literature lay buried under a barbarism that threatened to become perpetual, the language of the Romans, being divided into the clerical Latin and the popular Romance, and being rendered exceedingly corrupt, began after the reign of Charlemagne to improve by very slow but continuous steps. The church proceeded to write its decretals and its canons, and the jurisconsults their decisions, with a less barbarous latinity; and the various languages, as well those which were indigenous to the countries that were already conquered by the Romans, as those of the northern nations who afterwards overwhelmed the south, blended themselves with Romance dialects, so as to form the languages at this day so renowned for the works they have produced of philosophy, eloquence, and genius. It was somewhat after the twelfth century that the several provincial dialects began to assume a more national physiognomy; and the writings of that time bear the characters which distinguish the Romance in Spain, France, and Italy, – in three languages absolutely different.
Three causes mainly contributed to make the Tuscan dialect prevail beyond the others then spoken and written in Italy.

1. The Tuscans emigrated originally, at a most remote period of antiquity, from Africa and from Arabia; and having established themselves in Etruria, constantly maintained, in their pronunciation, that modulation of the vowels which is perceptible in all the southern languages, and which conduces so essentially to the harmony and melody of the Italian tongue, and renders it the most musical of modern idioms. The north of the Peninsula having been originally peopled by transalpine tribes, and afterwards governed, through a long succession of ages, by the Lombards, and other northern conquerors, retains dialects that are crowded with consonants, too tedious and impracticable to yield to the melody of music. The Venetians, from their continued commerce with the Greeks and with the East, and from their never having been invaded by the nations of the North, have preserved a dialect modulated by many vowels, and would, perhaps, have exalted it into a literary and national language; but the Tuscans proceeded under more favourable circumstances, and have profited by them wonderfully.

2. The Venetians reduced their democratic constitution into a rigorously aristocratic government; and consequently the few who governed, enslaved the intellect of the many, just at that very epoch when Florence and the other Tuscan cities revolted against the German emperors, destroyed the feudal aristocracies, and converted them into democratic republics. Their commerce, their navigation, their manufactures, the arts, and luxury, prospered as much as those of the Venetians, and with this essential difference, that every individual might freely develop his own talents. The same causes which contributed in Athens to the prosperity of letters, and the diffusion and celebrity of the Attic dialect, produced precisely similar effects in Florence. The people of either state passed at once to civilization, as if from the depth of barbarism; so that those arts which are the refinements of luxury and of the schools, had had neither sufficient time nor opportunity to weaken that impetuosity of passion, and that vigour of imagination, which in a half savage state are so favourable to poetry and eloquence, and on that account assist to enrich and perfect a language. Those Florentines who, from their genius and their education, aspired to the government of their republic, were obliged to procure the votes of a passionate, intractable, and ignorant people; and therefore they employed such words of the vulgar tongue as are the most simple, and always the most clear and forcible; and the genius of orators and authors polished and ennobled them. Every petty dealer, every indigent mechanic, deemed that his family was of essential importance to the state, and, in the same book where his accounts were kept, registered domestic and political events, with an elegant simplicity, a terseness and brevity, that belong to those who do not write to solicit the applauses of idle readers. Some of these journals are yet in existence; a few have been published; and all of them exhibit an orthography constantly uncertain, imperfect, and changeable, but at the same time a permanent propriety of expression, and a grammatical exactness, which are so much the more surprising, as there did not then exist among them any grammars or dictionaries. And while the histories and chronicles of all the other states of Italy were, with a miserable ambition, composed in pedantic Latin, the Florentines were emulous to write the annals of their country in their own native language.

3. They, however, wrote at that time rather Tuscan than Italian; and their dialect, although it was full of grace, correctness, and harmony, did not yet merit the title of a literary and national language. But Florence produced, contemporaneously as it were, three men, each of whom being gifted with a genius totally different from that of others, wrote in a manner admired by all Europe: and each of whom created for himself a new language that belonged to him alone. Dante, ingrafted upon the Tuscan dialect the most graceful, energetic, and musical idioms, that he could cull out of all the other dialects of Italy: Petrarca selected from the Provençal and the Catalonian all the elegancies that could be transfused into his verses, in such a way as to lose their foreign origin: And Boccaccio gave to his prose the dignity and rotundity of the Latin. Thenceforward Italy possessed a national and literary language – an "ideal" language, if we many be allowed the expression, because it was no longer popular, or spoken when Italy was no longer united and free. Hence it was that every great writer made use of that language, and of his own talent, to accumulate new figures and new riches, and to render it his own. Those indications that distinguish the excellent writers of all nations, are most prominent and most easily discerned in such of the Italian authors as merit the title of original. But in a country under the bondage of a religious inquisition, of a foreign despotism, and of the pedants of the schools, there cannot exist much originality – for slavery is the death of genius! The Italian language has a natural and an inviolable constitution, which is so much the more useful, as it is flexible to those who know how to examine and to apply it; but there is no language that in the same degree rejects the positive and often arbitrary laws of the arts of the grammarians. It appears to have been formed to serve men of genius, and to tyrannize over médiocre authors, with whom Italy abounds, and who seem condemned to meditate, not so much upon the matter they shall write, as upon how they may justify to the critics every phrase and every expression which they adopt in their compositions. Immediately after the age of Dante, of Petrarca, and Boccaccio, and for the space of more than a century, all the learned continued to write in Latin, to study Greek, and to discountenance a language that had the name of vulgar, and was left. to the people; to whom, however, both Dante and Petrarca were scarcely intelligible. No schoolmaster condescended to teach Italian; and youths accused of reading Italian books, were severely punished. Lorenzo de Medici and his friends were the first to renew the example of writing in their native language; but with all the study which they devoted to it, every one of them, more or less, wrote in a defective taste. Some affected latinity too much; others, the provincial peculiarities of the Florentine dialects; and the whole of them violated the essential rules of grammar. About this era, the dominion acquired by Charles V. in Europe produced in Italy foreign governments, or governments dependent upon foreigners, and universally despotic. There were no longer orators, because no one dared to speak the truth, but was obliged to be silent even as to what he knew to be false! Historians did not find events worthy of being related; and, in reality, the annals of the sixteenth, seventeenth, and eighteenth centuries, might be comprised in a very few pages, recording what have been the fields upon which foreigners have fought in Italy, and what the tributes which the Italians have ever been compelled to pay to the conquerors. To the poets alone, therefore, and because their verses abounded rather with adulation and amorous complaint than with philosophy and moral sentiment, the privilege was permitted of extolling the reigning houses, and their platonic mistresses. Thus, then, talents, naturally disposed to the cultivation of letters, found themselves under the alternative of preserving the most inactive silence, or of bending the language to rhyme, sonnets, and songs. This was the origin of the immense number of versifiers, and the frightful lack of readable prose in Italy. If, occasionally, it was the lot of genius to emancipate himself from his chains, he was constrained to look less for the applause of his contemporaries than for that of posterity. Ariosto, who, more than all the writers of the age of Leo X put together, enlarged and embellished the treasures of the language, – and Machiavelli, the greatest prose author whom Italy ever possessed, – these men, it seems, were at that time considered as authors, at the utmost, of the second rate. Shortly after the death of these two illustrious individuals, the Jesuits, who had taken upon themselves the instruction of those who were possessed of talent, subjected them, even from infancy, to the influence of every species of servile superstition. Before this period, authors not being at liberty to write what they thought, were still at least able to acquire the merit of expressing old things after a new manner, or to write their own language in their own style. But very soon afterwards, even this miserable privilege came to be denied to them by the masters and the critics of the Jesuits' colleges. That language, too, which even under Asiatic despotism is governed by the judgment of the nation that uses it, was reduced, as it were by a government decree, within laws that were discussed and established by grammarian cardinals, by universities of pedants, and by princes who presided over chartered academies, – chartered to compile a vocabulary which should thenceforth have the force and authority of a code of laws. Tasso, for having scorned to yield a servile acquiescence in the rules of these formidable grammarians, increased the cruel persecution which afflicted his unhappy life.

But the nature of a language that admits of being variously handled, according to the various genius of authors, – spoken dialects, in which these authors were obliged to think, in the first instance, in order £hat they might afterwards write and print in the literary language, – and lastly, provincial idioms, which authors neither could, nor desired entirely to avoid; these causes prevented the authority of the Academy Della Crusca from becoming inviolable and universal. From such circumstances were engendered doubts, questions, and new laws, which being multiplied, intricate, and obstinately combated and defended, served to fill volumes, not one of which can be read without weariness, while the whole of them did not suffice to make the disputants understand each other. All the contests which were commenced in the sixteenth century respecting the language, are still depending, and are in a course to be agitated anew among the Italians our contemporaries; so that if to Italian we give the appellation of "the Italian language", we shall do so at our peril, since it is not yet decided whether it is to be termed "the Italian", "the Tuscan", or the "Florentine".

Such controversies, however miserable they be, may often in the result prove of public utility, or probably contribute a few additional pages of ingenious eloquence to the stores of literature, provided the writer of them be animated with the noblest sentiments for his country. But Italy has, for a great length of time, been governed under such a political system, that sentiments of this kind are either repressed, or degenerate into those provincial animosities, that are always more excited by governments in proportion as it may answer their purposes to keep the nation disunited. It is, therefore, no matter of wonder, (although it cannot but bitterly disgust him who witnesses the fact), that the books which in these days make the greatest noise in Italy, are those that continue to argue, not upon moral or political truths, not upon principles and systems, not upon maxims which direct the conduct of life, or opinions that shape the destiny of intellect, not upon passions that warm and nourish the heart, – but upon questions that, departing from reason, and sentiment, and fact, tend only to establish the most rigorous laws, and to set bounds to the forms and modes of expressing the infinite conceptions and the spontaneous sensations of the mind and heart of man.

And although every new founder of these grammatical constitutions meets with opposition, and the more ancient statutes do not happen to be at present very much respected, the nation is in every matter accustomed to judge of the merits of an author, according to the praise or censure which the critics have passed upon his style. In such constant danger of the severe criticism of the legislators of the language, and in the midst of such a multitude of contradictions and theories, also the most profound thinkers, and individuals capable of feeling. vividly and of imagining boldly, are perplexed in the selection and use of words and phrases necessary for expressing the most original ideas, and the most lively passions, and the most striking images which their fancy has created. So that among a people who possess the most harmonious, the most flexible, and the most energetic of languages, the man of genius, whom nature has formed to give creation, nobility, and animation to words, sees himself constrained, under the double tyranny of princes and of pedants, to resign himself to silence. Meanwhile, the host of writers is divided into two furious factions; the one contending for a style of writing impregnated with new words from foreign languages, and with terms borrowed from every science, while the other excommunicates as a corrupt barbarism every word which cannot be discovered to have been used by the Tuscan authors of the fourteenth century. The neologists renounce their nation, the "purists" their age; and in the meanwhile, both the one party and the other are marring a language, beautiful in itself, and the only possession that yet remains to their unfortunate country!

div2.n: Italian literature: Epoch First from 1180 to 1230
div2.head: ITALIAN LITERATURE: EPOCH FIRST FROM THE YEAR 1180 TO 1230
div2.p:
Intending to take a view in regular portions of the different epochs of Italian literature, – which, as being the most ancient and the most copious of all the modern, may contribute most materially to the history of civilization and of literary criticism, – we have in the preceding Number glanced over the vicissitudes of the Italian tongue from its first dawn to the present day:
Ausi sumus Italorum
Omne ævum tribus explicare chartis.
– Jupiter! –

At this classic exclamation, which we already hear resounding ironically from Italy, where for every ten years of literary history a man has to wade through ten volumes, we shall reply with an observation perhaps not uncommon, but not on that account less applicable: it is this, that whoever, before he begins to write, has not the whole of his subject arrayed before his mind, must necessarily go a long way about in search of it, and after all find both himself and his readers in a maze; hence the infinity of volumes in which so much is read, and yet so very little gained by the reading. On the contrary, whoever would see clearly the spot from which he starts, and the place at which he has to arrive, and through what roads, and with what purpose, and what certainty of proving useful, will do wisely to follow the example of geographers. They usually prefix a map of vast territories, traced with the most minute and almost imperceptible indications, which proves of the greatest utility to travellers, in allowing them to take a clear and uninterrupted view of the various provinces of every kingdom which they wish to examine, divided and subdivided into partial maps on a larger scale. It is true, that the plan and variety indispensable in a periodical work would not admit of the necessary number of divisions; and, even the. few that are indispensable, ought to be restricted within narrow limits. In order, therefore, to unite brevity with clearness, the epochs which we proceed to examine shall be divided in periods of fifty years each. Every article will in this manner comprehend the history of the Italian language of one epoch only; – notice will be taken of those eminent writers only whose compositions served as models to the age which they rendered illustrious by their genius; – such facts only will be adduced, as have either not been heretofore sufficiently illustrated, or from which preceding writers have not derived all the advantages which they might have done, in drawing from them principles and conclusions applicable to history and literature in general. We confess – and without affecting the title of modesty – that for all, or almost all, the facts to which we allude, we are indebted to other writers; but at the same time, without any apprehension of incurring the charge of vanity, we declare once for all, that the reflections suggested by such facts, the various consequences deduced from them, and the general principles at which we perhaps arrive – be they true, false, or questionable; new, or already discovered by others – are not borrowed from the works of others.

It may with truth be said, that Italians, and in this respect every stranger who was a lover of their language could but imitate them, have been so dazzled with the splendour of the epoch of Dante, Petrarca, and Boccaccio, that they have not been able to discern those lesser lights, which, though faint when confronted which their radiance, and scattered at long intervals, have from time to time brought into the traces ofdawning civilization, and its silent progress through the darkness and barbarism of the middle ages. Civilization principally depends upon the quantity and greater certainty of ideas; and ideas depend upon literature, and literature upon the languages of nations: he, therefore, who best succeeds in tracing the origin of a language which has become a literary one, and served as a means of diffusing and embellishing human knowledge, will be best enabled to form the most just deduction relative to the history of the civilization of every nation. But an attempt to trace the remote and obscure origin of the Italian language would, perchance, be a labour incited rather by curiosity than utility, if the knowledge that might redound from it were not applicable to other times and countries. Now, whoever admits the principle, and we think there are few who will feel disposed to deny it, that nature always proceeds in her operations in one manner, and invariably ordains that the same effects should follow from the same causes, will feel sorry that, in the midst of the general avidity for knowledge, a better use has not been made of those dates and documents which, though few in number, might have assisted in giving us an insight into the mode in which the Italian language was formed; and thence, by proceeding from the known to the less known, form some useful conjectures relative to the origin and progress of other languages. The Greek language may be traced historically almost to the Iliad; but, as in that poem the language and the poetry. have arrived at such perfection, we are unable to form higher conjectures. Hence the Greeks say, that their language sprung forth at once, with all its energy, its riches, and its harmony, from the genius of Homer, as Pallas armed complete from the brain of Jupiter: and the Italians in the same manner are fond of declaring, that their language, which in truth is but little inferior to the Greek, sprung forth, throve, and came to perfection in the course of half a century, from the genius of Dante, of Petrarca, and of Boccaccio.

The language of Federigo resembles the Provençal Roman, which was divided into many dialects, some of which assimilate to the French, as it is now spoken in Marseilles, with some modifications produced by time; while the others varied in no great respect from that Italian which is spoken in our days by the people of Nizza, from which the dialect of the Canzonetta of the Emperor differs but in a trifling degree:

Now who does not see that the predominant vowels in the pronunciation of the people of the south are more frequent, and produce longer modulations, in the verses that bear a nearer alliance to the Italian language? and that in proportion as the Roman verses approximate more nearly to the Teutonic, they are more harsh through the articulation of the consonants naturally prevalent in all the languages of the north?

The nu (now) twice employed by Ottfrid, is an. evident abbreviation of the Latin nunc; in the same manner, vuill and scriban are the verbs volo and scribo; Evangeliono is the Latin Evangelium; and zungun – whence is derived the English substantive song, and the verb sing – though imagined by some to be of Teutonic origin, has certainly its root in the sonum of the Latins, from whence comes the sonetto of the Provençal and of the Italians. There were no verses in those days but what were accompanied by music or sound. Music, which in our days is more instrumental than vocal, was then quite the contrary; the dance was then led by the singing of verses set to music, nor were they ever separated. Thence the sonum, which with the Latins meant exclusively sound, came in the middle age to signify generally words accompanied by metre and song.

The Teutonic derivations observable in the ten lines of Federigo are fewer than those from the Latin in the four lines of the German monk; and although in the Roman Italian dialect the language of Virgil is found mutilated or barbarized, yet, if I may so express it, the fragrance of the classics remains like that which breathes from the leaves of a withered rose. The phrase corps Aragonnes cannot be literally translated with grace, nor perhaps with decency, into every modern language; and yet it recalls the energetic elegance in which, in the Æneid, we see presented suddenly to – our eyes, and without any veil, the beauty of the forms of the immortal followers of Juno:
"Sunt mihi bis septem præstanti corpore Nymphæ,
Quarum, quæ forma pulcherrima, Deïopeiam"
whence latterly Monti derived his beautiful verse
"Sette bei corpi di Dardanie donne".

The word kara, which we have translated face, literally complexion, was by the Italians, posterior to Federigo, pronounced cera, and is gracefully employed by a very ancient poet:
Ben passa rosa e fiore,
La vostra gentil cera
Lucente più che spera.
Soon passes rose and flower
And soon thy sweet complexion,
More lucid than a mirror.
The ancients, however, employed the word carnagione in the same sense, and it was afterwards preferred by writers as more noble; in fact, in virtue of its length, it never became domesticated with the popular idiom, in which cera was adopted. The spoken language has always a tendency to adopt short vowels, o and when they are long it shortens and mutilates them. Hence, in the Greek and French languages, and particularly in the English, many letters, especially vowels, are written but not pronounced. Nor would it have been otherwise in Italy, had not the various provinces spoken their particular dialects and the national language remained absolutely literary. In the introduction to this series of articles, we have advanced as a general observation, that all the peculiar characteristics and inexplicable phenomena of the national Italian language are derived from its having been always written and never spoken. Hence its autography not having to conform itself to the changes and caprices of the popular pronunciation, remained untouched and uniform in books of some past ages, so that the alphabetical signs of every written word are exactly expressed by the modulation and articulation of the voice of the reader. As for the rest, the idiomatical word cera, as well as the word carnagione, are both derived from the Roman kara, and are only modifications of the Latin caro (flesh). Innumerable other words might, in the same manner, be adduced to show by what process the pure language of the Romans has been metamorphosed into barbarous Latin, – in the Roman dialect common to Europe in the middle age – in the Roman dialect as modified and peculiar to different countries – in various national languages; finally, in one only written language, which however was not spoken in Italy, though sometimes enriched and sometimes spoiled by many provincial dialects, all originating from the same single source. Thus in languages, as in all other things, nature pursues the same method as is displayed in the multiplication of vegetables, the seeds of which, according to the diversity of soil or of cultivation, whether artificial or spontaneous, produce innumerable varieties. The almond tree gradually becomes a peach tree by the industrious mode of culture pursued by Mr Knight; and the bulb of the girasole of the markets of Florence, is transformed into the Jerusalem artichoke of the market of Covent Garden.

Those who, like Voltaire, can investigate, discovering in these remnants of antiquity not only the origin and the metamorphosis of languages, but also the genius, manners, and history of nations, will observe in these verses of Federigo, that neither a series of ages, a variety of revolutions, nor the wide diffusion of knowledge, have been able to alter all the characteristics that distinguish the different people of the middle age. The bon ton of French chivalry was doomed to pass through the sanculotism of democracy and the janisarism, under Napoleon, and is now perhaps about to be infected with the raging fanaticism of the ultras under the Bourbons; but it is not yet so far lost as not to leave abundant traces of its existence. The Spaniards still continue to court the fair with a warmth of devotion and of gallantry unknown to the other Europeans. The Arragonese dames are still celebrated for their graceful carriage, for which they are indebted to the fine proportion of their forms. We know not whether the Trevisan are still distinguished for their grace and agility in the dance; but certainly these graces spring up more spontaneously in that part of Italy, where the ladies have more ease, vivacity, and gaiety in their actions, their thoughts, and their dialect. It is to the complexion and countenance which the Emperor Federigo admired in the English ladies, that they are principally indebted for that pleasing sense which they produce in the mind of a stranger, when seen by him for the first time; and did but the fire of Italian beauty breathe from their countenance, they would assuredly be the most dangerous among the daughters of Eve. They still continue, generally, to possess hands of a handsome form; and if the imperial poet was not struck with their feet, it is to be attributed only to his chivalrous gallantry. The compliment paid to the Genoese has been changed in the manufacture of Voltaire, who, in place of onrar,
Essai sur les moeurs, cap. LXXXII. the contraction of onorar, reads ouvrar; and, in fact, they served as manufacturers, navigators, and bankers, which is but another name for usurers, to nearly the whole of Europe. They were, at all events, neither more nor less than a nation of shopkeepers, who, in all countries, are the best and most dexterous masters of ceremonies, and the most eloquent of orators, in the persuasion and flattery which they employ to coax into a bargain. The youths in Tuscany are still remarkable for their beauty and vivacity of countenance; they served as models to many of the ancient painters of angels, among whom were Mantegna and Frate Angelico; the latter of whom we name because he was one of the best deserving, though least celebrated, restorers of the fine arts in Florence. What is meant by the Perle Jullienne we are unable to guess, nor can we learn from any writer. And here it is but just to observe one thing which others have passed unnoticed, – that it appears that Federigo I. did not think the Germans, over whom he reigned, deserving of being numbered among civilized nations. He cultivated the Roman poetry as the great Frederick king of Prussia did the French; and both the one and the other treated their subjects and fellow-citizens as barbarians, fit for no other purpose than to kill and be killed in battle. This want of patriotism in the elder Federigo was more pardonable, since the smaller portion of. his dominions was in Germany, where, with the exception of the priests and their theological studies, and certain chroniclers in wretched Latin, there did not exist a language capable, of being written in except the Roman. We have seen that the monk Ottfrid, in order to make the Germans understand the gospel, professed to translate it into the Roman French, and only succeeded in translating it into the Roman Teutonic. Equally did the long residence of Federigo in Italy lead him to adopt the Roman dialect, then most in use among the Lombard troubadours.

Italy, however, possessed fewer troubadours than France and Spain; and even those few carried the arts of war, of rhyme, and of love, into foreign countries, courting the patronage, of kings, counts, and barons, who divided Europe among themselves, parcelling it out into many petty divisions. Had not the genius, the extraordinary character, and the romantic history of Sordello, impelled the curiosity of posterity to disinter his poetry, it might, to this day, have been the belief that the Italians had never been troubadours. It appears that the fame Sordello did not rest, as that of every other poet of that period, upon the verses which he addressed to the ladies; although all the French and Italian authors, studious of literary antiquities, have erred when, copying each other, they have, asserted that there is no amatory poetry of Sordello existing. Tiraboschi notices many examples of this kind, and M. Renouard published some beautiful specimens of them in Paris. Indeed Sordello was in love with a variety of ladies, and was sometimes loved by them in return: there was not a fair dame at this period who did not take a pleasure in confessing her weakness towards a troubadour of celebrity, or who would not have blushed at a lover who was not capable of celebrating her charms in verse. Still the times, the fortunes, and the character of Sordello, conspired with his genius to give him the reputation of being the most powerful artificer of a lofty and indignant kind of poetry, that fulminated bitter truths and defiance against princes. From the stanzas we are about to cite, it would appear that in the whole of Europe he saw but one hero; and that he was the friend of Blacas, a powerful baron, a troubadour, and a warrior. Upon occasion of his death, Sordello being afflicted at the idea that the world had lost the only man who set an example of true magnanimity and valour, sent to all the monarchs of Europe the heart of Blacas, that they might divide it among themselves, and, by eating a portion of it, procure that courage which nature had denied them.
Planger vuoil' en Blacaz en aquest leger son
Ab cor trist e marrit: et aien ben rason.
Ch' en lui mescabat ai segnor et amie bon,
E car lutt laip valent en sa mort perdut son
Tant es mortal lo dans, che non hai soispeisson
Che jamai si revegna, se 'n tal guisa non
Ch' om li tragga lo cor, e che 'n manjon i baron
Che vivon descorat: poi s' avran de' cor pron.
Primier mangie del cor, persochè gran ops l'es,
L'emperaire de Roma, se il vol los Milanes
Per forsa conquistar, car lui tenon conques,
E vio desertat malgrat de sos ties
E de seguentre manien lo reis Frances,
Poi cobrarà sa terra ch' el perd par sa nescies.
Ma s' il creirà sa mare, el non mangerà ges
Car ben par son pretz ch' el non fai ren che il pes.
Del rei Angles mi plats, car es pane coratios
Che manie pro' del cor, poi ser' valens e bos,
Che cobrarà la terra, per que viv dè pretz blos
Qu' il tol lo rei de Fransa car lo sap nuaillos.
E lo rei Castellan teng ch' en mang per un dos:
Car dos regesmes ten, e non es per un pros.
Ma s' il en vol manjar, teng qu' en maing a rescos
Che s' il mare o sapia batrial al bastos.
Del rei d'Arragon voil, ge del cor deja manjar,
Ch' epso il farà de l' anta descargar
Qu' un ano sai de Marseilla e de Meilan contar.
Non pot estiers per re que sapcha dir, ne far.
Et apress voil del cor donom al rei d' Navar,
Che valia mas coms che rei: sò unch contar.
Forto es quan dieus fai hom en gran ricor pojar:
Poi sofraicha de cor 1o fa de pretz bassar.
Al conte di Tolosa es ops que ne mang ben,
S' il membra so qu' el tener, ni so que ten,
Car si ab antro cor sa preda non reven,
Non par che ja revegna ab quel c' ha en sen.
El Comt Provensal taing qu' en mang e si il conven:
Ch' om che deseretalz viv gaire, non val rien.
E si tot ab effortz si diffend, nis capten,
Ops l' es manie del cor pel grev fais q' el sosten.
Li baron m' volran mal de so' qu' ien die ver:
Mas ben sapihat, qu' ien il pretz atant pane, com ill me
Bel restaurs, sol c' ab vos posea trobar mercè,
A mon dan get cascun que per amie non m' ten.
Translation.
With heavy heart for Blacasso I mourn,
And mourn with reason, for in him I've lost
My lord and friend, and in his funeral urn
All his brave deeds are buried; and the host
Of daunted Barons now will never learn
How to repair the ills his death has cost,
Unless they take his heart so bold and tough,
And on it feed –then they'll have heart enough.
And let the Roman Emperor be the first
Who eats of it, since mighty is his need;
If he the Milanese by force would worst,
Who now have worsted him, and made him lead,
Maugre his Germans, an existence curst:
Then to regain his land let France too feed.
But not if he'll be counsell'd by his mother,
And do those acts which please him, and no other.
Since little courage hath the English King,
Let him upon that heart feed lustily;
Then he'll be wise and good, and once more bring
Beneath his sway the realms France made him flee:
Let Castile's King eat twice, whose royal wing
Is o'er two kingdoms spread, but let it be
In secret, lest his mother catch him tasting,
And by a stick reward him with a basting.
If Arragon's King eats of it, he may
Wipe off his shame at Marseilles and Milan;
There's nothing else that he can do or say
Will aught avail. Navarre's King's next, who can
Scarce rank above a count. Oh! it is gay
When in his riches only Heaven makes man
Reliance place – then let him have a slice,
Since eating of the heart will lower the price.
Then let the Count of Toulouse eat; his breast
Does not now hold a heart which can regain
What he has lost. Then, if he likes, the rest
Give to the Count of Provence; he who fain
Would live when all he prized is from him wrest,
Is good for nothing. If he fails again
And falls in prison, then the heart he's eaten
Will bear his courage up, when bound and beaten.
The Barons wish me in, because the truth
Is on my lips; and ev'n so let it be,
For it is known to all men that in sooth
I prize them just as lightly as they me:
Oh! Lady, my sweet comforter! do thou
But smile upon me, and let who will bend
Their brows with frowns; then my hot wrath will blow
Away all those who do not call me friend.

To offer a human heart by way of a dainty viand, appears to have been no unusual compliment. Among those novels of Boccaccio in which he departs but, very little from historical fact, there is one in which the lady of Castle Roussillon is made unconsciously to eat the heart of her lover, murdered in a wood by her husband, who had afterwards taken out the lover's heart, and caused it to be cooked in the most exquisite manner. The circumstances, as they are related by the French historians, are still more horrible. In the novel, the husband is content with discovering to his wife the nature of the delicacy upon which she has been feeding; but the historians, aspiring perhaps to produce a more tragical effect, represent the husband as showing to his wife, after supper, the amputated and bleeding head of her wretched lover. The modern drama, in which another lady receives the heart of her lover as a present from her husband, is also founded upon a story of the crusades. In fine, in the ancient French novels, twelve husbands combine to kill a chevalier, who had been the lover of their twelve wives, tear out his heart, and, at a feast given for that purpose, cause it to be presented as a choice dish to all the ladies at once.
Tableaux du douzième et du treizième siècle. Vol. III. It would appear, therefore, that in these days descriptions of atrocities of this kind awakened neither in the writer nor the reader the disgust which in our age they would be sure to excite. Sordello, in compliance with the taste of his contemporaries for stories of horror, gave a proof of a less depraved taste, and of greater originality. The distribution of human hearts minced up into ragouts, excites less horror, because it is not represented as a fact; and the motive of such an ironical invitation to this banquet, (forming the noblest eulogium that the poet could have paid his friend), is the bitter contempt merited by the princes of those times.

The verses, even when translated literally into prose, are full of vigour, and the ideas, though common, possess a fire and a novelty of expression peculiar to the ancient poets, who wrote from native feeling and reflection, as the learned almost always through art and reminiscence. Dante extols Sordello "as a man of marvellous eloquence, who contributed to found the national language of Italy; for neither in writing nor speaking did he employ his native Mantuan dialect, but attentively studying the various dialects of Verona, Cremona, Brescia, and other cities of that part of Italy, selected the words best fitted to form a language, the elements of which, though derived from the vulgar tongue, yet, when combined with elegance and harmony, formed a style less vulgar, and better adapted for eloquence and poetry
Ut Sordellus de Mantuâ suâ ostendit, Cremonæ, Brixiæ, atque Veronae confini; qui tantus eloquentiæ vir existens, non solum in poetando, sed quomodo libet loquendo patrium vulgare deseruit. Eloq., lib. I, cap. 15. We quote the original words, because they evidently prove that a national tongue had already sprung up, and was making rapid advances, not only in Tuscany but in Lombardy, an age before Dante; and that although the poetry of Sordello had the Provençal form, it was nevertheless composed of words in use among the Italians. The model of the words employed by Sordello belongs, it is true, to the Roman dialect, but the roots are all Latin, and with the same modifications that, at the present day, distinguish the literary language of Italy from all those that originated from the same Latin source. A learned man made the experiment, and succeeded, with a very few alterations in the sound, in reducing all the words in the stanzas of Sordello into as many others of the written Italian language of our days.
Perticari, Dell'amor patrio di Dante
Another writer made a different experiment with respect to the historical allusions of these stanzas, translating and applying them to the crowned heads who reigned during the dictatorship of Bonaparte. He exhorted them to put him to death, and to divide his brains among them by way of a relish. The only one among the sovereigns of that period to whom this piece of advice would not have applied, was then living unknown even to himself, and afflicted by calamity that rendered doubly malignant the invitation to banquet on the brains of a man who was at that time thought omnipotent by the sole vigour of his mind. Whether the secret history of the monarchs of the age of Sordello resembled that of the reigning houses of our days, posterity will know better than we can – provided the human race shall still persist in feeling an interest in such gossip. Those, however, who would fain know sufficient royal anecdotes of our own time to institute a comparison with those alluded to by Sordello, may recur to the histories and lives of the Emperor Frederick II. of St Louis IX. king of France, of Henry III. of England, of St Ferdinand III. of Castile, and he will readily learn more than enough to illustrate these few stanzas with a volume of learned comments.

A more difficult task is that of disentangling certain facts from the romantic inventions in which, during the middle ages, the life of Sordello was enveloped. There can be no doubt that during his lifetime he enjoyed an extraordinary degree of celebrity, otherwise posterity would not have attributed to him a character without a parallel, and the performance of the most incredible exploits. It is correct to say posterity, for few of his contemporaries were able to write; and the history of his life, of which the manuscript existed both in the Provençal and Italian dialect, does not appear to have been composed till a long time after his death. It is probable that the Provençal is the oldest, and dates about the thirteenth century, and that the Italian is but a translation of it made in the succeeding century, as is the case with many other works of the same kind, although some Italian critics are fond of having it believed that the latter is the original. The following specimen will serve to illustrate both the romantic character attributed to Sordello, and the state of the Italian language at that epoch.
Extract from an Ancient Manuscript. Sordel fo' Mantovano d'un castel che à nome Goito: gentil cattano: fo' avvinente omo della persona, e grande amatore. Ma molto el fo' scaltro, e falso verso le donne, e verso e' baroni da cui fistava. E s'intese in Madonna Cunizza, sorore de Ser Eccelino e deSer Alberico da Romano, ch'eramogliera del Conte de Santo Bonifacio. E per volontate de Ser Eccelino el involò Madonna Cunizza, facio;e menolla via. Poco apresso et else n'andette nell'Onedese ad un castel de quelli d'Estrue, da Ser Enrico, e da Ser Guillelm, e da Ser Valpertino ch'erano molto suoi amici. Ed isposovvi una sua sorore celatamente ch'avia nome Madonna Otta. Vennesene poi aTreviso. E quando quel d'Estrue lo seppe, sì lo volia offendere dela persona. E li amici del Contede Santo Bonifacio issamente: Dond'ello istava armato suso in la casa de Misser Eccelino.
Quand'el andava per la terrael cavalcava un bono destriere agrande compagnia di cavalieri. Per paura di quelli che il volian offendere el si parti, ed andossen eraProvenza et istette dal Conte di Provenza: e ivi amò una gentildonna e bella: ed appellavalane' suoi cantari ch' el facia per lei: Dolce enemica. Per la qualdonna el fece mante bone canzoni.
Translations in Old English. Sordello was of the countrie of Mantua, of a castle called Goito a valliant captaine, well favoured in his person, and a great lover of the ladies. But he was cunninge and fausse towards them and the princes with whom he dwelled. He had an intrigue with the Ladie Cunizza, sister of Sir Eccelino and of Sir Alberico da Romano, and wife of the Count of San Bonifacio and with the consente and pleasure of Sir Eccelino, Sordello ran away with the Ladie Cunizza. Afterwards he went into the countries of Onedese, to a castel belonging to the Lords of Estrae, to wit, the three brothers, Sir Henri, Sir William, and Sir Valpertino, who where his great friends, and espoused in secrete their sister the Ladie Otta. Then he went to Treviso. When the Lords of Estrae saw this, they saughte to kill him. And the friends of the Count of San Bonifacio endeavoured to do the like. So he alwaies kept himself armed in the castel of Sir Eccelino.
Now when Sordello lefte the castel, he rode on a goodlie horse, and was surrounded by a numeros and goodlie companie of knights. At last to escape being killed by his enemies he went into Provence, and dwelled with the Count of Provence; and there he fell in love with a fine dame, for whom he made poetrie, and he called her his sweet enemie. In truth he made for this ladie many fine songis.

In this ancient manuscript there is no end to his gallantries. Sordello is _ a knight-errant, more amorous though less mad than Orlando, and not less formidable to the whole universe. For want of better authority, historians have been content to follow such manuscripts, probably unwilling to part with a character so well calculated to embellish their pages. When no documents exist to impugn the truth of their narrations, such writers have good play; they can go on with impunity; and it is at these times that they are found to deal so largely in the marvellous. Platina himself, whose chronological lives of the Popes drew down such persecution on him during life, and after his death secured him a place among the martyrs in the cause of truth, presents us in his history of Mantua with details so marvellous, that Ariosto would have hesitated to admit them into verse. He states Sordello to have been born at Goito near Mantua, in 1189, and speaks of him as one of the noble progenitors of the house of Visconti. He describes him as of middling stature, with a fine countenance, extremely active, habituated to endure fatigue, and of a warm and voluptuous temperament, though, at the same time, capable of severe privations; of an enterprising courage, never refusing a challenge, fighting almost daily, and yet coming off triumphant in every combat. We have neither the space nor the inclination to enter into a detail of all the great and heroic exploits recorded of him, even by Platina. It is recorded of him that he besieged the virtue of the noblest dames and princesses of Italy and of Europe, not one of whom was proof against his attacks; nay more, the historian gravely gives a list of the names of those who were added to his conquests. We see him provoking the most formidable warriors to measure the lance with him, and after having vanquished them, instead of deigning to keep them as his prisoners, sending them as presents to the different monarchs of Europe. Nothing can equal the haughty disdain with which he treats different princes, yet they are happy to invite him to their courts and to load him with honours and presents, because without his aid it was impossible either to gain a battle, to capture or defend a fortress, or to conclude a treaty of peace and alliance. Such is the substance of many a long page of Platina's history, who was seduced into falsehoods from a love of his country, the historian and his hero being equally of Mantua. Influenced by other motives, other writers have gone still farther; some, to gratify their readers with royal scandal, others to make it appear that they knew things with which the rest of the world was unacquainted. Actuated by the latter motive, Volaterranus makes out Sordello to be a reigning prince, nay, the founder of the dynasty of the Dukes of Mantua. We might swell our pages with fresh names, the authority of which is nearly equal to that of Platina; but what we have already said is sufficient to show, that there is perhaps no writer on the subjects of Sordello whose veracity is to be depended upon. Many historians who are conscientious in not deviating from truth, have no scruple, when pressed by necessity, to have recourse to imagination, by borrowing the facts which they are anxious to establish from popular tradition, without which they would find themselves entirely at fault.

There is no doubt that among the troubadours there were, in the first instance, several men of consideration, some great warriors, and even persons of princely rank. The most ancient, if not the first examples of their poetry, of their singular actions, and warlike and voluptuous life, occur towards the eleventh century, under Willliam Duke of Aquitain. The rules of their poetical art. called gaja scienza (merry science), did not come till two ages after. But merriment was, from the beginning their inspiring muse. They led a life of perpetual warfare and agitation; they lost, recovered, and lost again their dominions, in almost no time; their courts displayed great pomp and prodigality, which were maintained by their violent and frequently fraudulent extortions; the love of glory, and a punctilious sense of honour, inspired them with feelings of magnanimity and sometimes of cruelty: revenge was the first of their social obligations, and that which was the most prompt, the most inhuman, and obtained by means of the most artful expedients, differing but little from treachery, was the vengeance most applauded. The same religion that subdued and softened, tended also to irritate their passions: they built churches, founded monasteries, warred to deliver the sepulchre of Christ, and supported that war with money extorted from their subjects, or plundered from peaceful travellers. To soothe the perpetual inquietudes of so stormy a mode of life and feeling, they had recourse to the pleasures of the table, to the dance, to love, and to the charms of verse; and without perhaps having read a verse of Horace, they followed the advice given by Chiron to Achilles at his setting out for Troy.
"Illic omne malum vino cantuque levato,
Deformis ægrimoniæ dulcibus alloquiis".
Hor., Epod.
We know not whether the Grecian hero sung verses of love; but when the troubadour princes sung of arms and of knights, they were not, as poets, very different from Achilles.
And now arrived where on the sandy bay
The Myrmidonian tents and vessels lay,
Amus'd, at ease, the godlike man they found,
Pleased with the solemn harp's melodious sound.
(The well-wrought harp from conquer'd Thebæ came,
Of polish'd silver was its costly frame).
With this he soothes his angry soul, and sings
The immortal deeds of heroes and of kings.
Il., IX.
